title: 108_s303
content: The "Human Cloning Ban and Stem Cell Research Protection Act of 2003" aims to prohibit human cloning and safeguard important medical research areas like stem cell research. It introduces a new chapter in Title 18 of the United States Code titled "Prohibition on Human Cloning." The "Prohibition on Human Cloning" section defines key terms like human cloning, human somatic cell, nuclear transplantation, nucleus, and oocyte. The "Prohibition on Human Cloning" section prohibits conducting human cloning, shipping nuclear transplantation products for cloning purposes, and exporting unfertilized blastocysts to countries that allow human cloning. The section prohibits human cloning, shipping nuclear transplantation products for cloning, and exporting blastocysts to countries allowing cloning. It includes criminal and civil penalties for violations. The curr_chunk states that property related to subsection (b) may be forfeited to the United States. It also clarifies that there is no private right of action under this section. SEC. 102. Oversight reports on actions to enforce certain prohibitions. The Comptroller General will prepare a report on the Attorney General's enforcement actions under Chapter 16 of Title 18, including personnel, resources, and any violations. State laws define "similar State law relating to human cloning" as laws imposing criminal penalties on individuals conducting or attempting human cloning. The Comptroller General will report on these laws and actions taken by State attorneys general for enforcement. The Comptroller General will report on how the Attorney General coordinates enforcement actions among federal, state, and local governments regarding violations of laws related to human cloning. The Attorney General coordinates enforcement of violations of federal laws on human cloning with state and local enforcement actions. The report also covers the status of appellate and civil litigation related to human cloning laws. Additionally, the Comptroller General will report on international laws on human cloning within a year of the Act's enactment. The Comptroller General will submit a report to the Senate and House Judiciary Committees detailing foreign laws on human cloning, enforcement actions by foreign countries, and international efforts to ban human cloning. Title II of the Public Health Service Act is amended to include ethical requirements for nuclear transplantation research, such as informed consent, institutional review board review, and protection for safety and privacy. Definitions for the terms 'donating', 'fertilization', and 'valuable consideration' are provided in this section, with valuable consideration excluding certain payments related to oocyte transportation and research. The text chunk discusses regulations regarding nuclear transplantation research, compensation for oocyte donation, and the prohibition of transplanting somatic cell nucleus into fertilized human oocytes. It also mentions the restriction on maintaining unfertilized blastocysts for more than 14 days. The text chunk outlines regulations for voluntary oocyte donation in nuclear transplantation research, emphasizing informed consent and prohibiting the purchase or sale of oocytes. It also mandates the separation of in vitro fertilization laboratories from locations where nuclear transplantation is conducted. The regulations prohibit conducting transplantation in labs with human oocytes undergoing assisted reproductive technology. Violators may face civil penalties up to $250,000.
